Potato Early Blight.symptom: Dark brown concentric (target-like) spots on older leaves, leading to yellowing, leaf drop, and reduced yield
Potato Early Blight.treatment: Use disease-free seed tubers, apply fungicides such as mancozeb or chlorothalonil, remove infected debris, and practice crop rotation

Potato Healthy.symptom: Leaves are green, uniform, and free from spots, wilting, or discoloration

Potato Late Blight.symptom: Water-soaked lesions on leaves and stems that quickly turn brown or black, often with white fungal growth under humid conditions; rapid plant collapse
Potato Late Blight.treatment: Apply systemic fungicides such as metalaxyl or cymoxanil, remove infected plants, ensure good field drainage, and avoid overhead irrigation

Tomato Bacterial Spot.symptom: Small dark brown to black spots with yellow halos on leaves and fruits, leading to defoliation and rough, scabby fruit lesions
Tomato Bacterial Spot.treatment: Apply copper-based bactericides, avoid overhead irrigation, use certified disease-free seed and resistant varieties

Tomato Early Blight.symptom: Dark brown spots with concentric rings on lower leaves, causing yellowing, drying, and premature leaf drop
Tomato Early Blight.treatment: Apply fungicides such as mancozeb or chlorothalonil, remove infected plant debris, maintain proper spacing, and use resistant varieties

Tomato Healthy.symptom: Leaves are green, turgid, and uniform with no spots, lesions, or discoloration

Tomato Late Blight.symptom: Large water-soaked, irregular lesions on leaves and stems, often with white mold growth on the underside during humid conditions
Tomato Late Blight.treatment: Use resistant varieties, remove infected plants immediately, apply systemic fungicides like metalaxyl, and avoid prolonged leaf wetness

Tomato Leaf Mold.symptom: Yellow patches on the upper leaf surface with olive-green to gray mold growth on the underside, especially in high humidity
Tomato Leaf Mold.treatment: Improve ventilation, reduce humidity, avoid overhead watering, and apply fungicides such as chlorothalonil or copper oxychloride

Tomato Septoria Leaf Spot.symptom: Numerous small circular spots with dark borders and grayish centers on lower leaves, progressing upward
Tomato Septoria Leaf Spot.treatment: Remove infected leaves, improve air circulation, avoid wet foliage, and apply protective fungicides like chlorothalonil

Tomato Spider Mites.symptom: Tiny yellow or white speckling on leaves, fine webbing on undersides, bronzing, and eventual leaf drop under heavy infestation
Tomato Spider Mites.treatment: Use miticides or neem oil, increase humidity, wash foliage with water spray, and remove heavily infested leaves

Tomato Target Spot.symptom: Brown circular lesions with concentric rings on leaves and sometimes on fruits, causing premature leaf fall
Tomato Target Spot.treatment: Use crop rotation, avoid overcrowding, improve airflow, and apply fungicides such as azoxystrobin or chlorothalonil

Tomato Mosaic Virus.symptom: Light and dark green mosaic mottling on leaves, leaf distortion, reduced vigor, and stunted growth
Tomato Mosaic Virus.treatment: No chemical cure; remove infected plants, disinfect tools, avoid tobacco contamination, and use resistant varieties

Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus.symptom: Upward curling and yellowing of leaves, stunted plants, and severe reduction in fruit set
Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus.treatment: Control whiteflies using traps or insecticides, use virus-free seedlings, employ resistant cultivars, and remove infected plants
